name: Calouste Gulbenkian
subtitle: Entrepreneur and philanthropist
bio:
Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian (1869–1955) was born in Constantinople to an Armenian family. He studied engineering in London and entered the oil industry in the late 19th century, becoming a mediator between governments and major companies.

In the 1920s he played a key role in the formation of the Iraq Petroleum Company, where he secured 5% of the shares, which gave him the nickname 'Mr. Five Percent'.

Gulbenkian was also a major art collector. His collection included European paintings, oriental carpets, manuscripts and antiquities. After his death, this became the basis of the Calouste Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon.

According to his will, a foundation was established to support projects in science, culture and education, which continues its work today.

name: Alexander Mantashov
subtitle: Oil industrialist and philanthropist
bio:
Alexander Mantashov (1842–1911) was born in Tiflis. He initially traded textiles in France and Russia, later investing in the oil industry in Baku. By the end of the 19th century he became one of the leading entrepreneurs in the region.

His company owned oil fields, refineries and distribution networks, competing with the largest firms in Russia and Europe and securing a place in the international market.

He allocated part of his income to the construction of schools, churches and theaters. He also financed book publishing and supported Armenian students abroad.

By the early 20th century Mantashov was considered one of the wealthiest businessmen in the Russian Empire. His name is often mentioned in the history of Baku oil and Armenian philanthropy.

name: Kirk Kerkorian
subtitle: Entrepreneur, investor
bio:
Kirk Kerkorian (1917–2015) was born in Fresno, California, to an Armenian family. During World War II he served in aviation. After the war he went into business, including aviation services and construction.

From the 1960s he invested heavily in the hotel industry of Las Vegas. He was involved in the construction of the International Hotel and the MGM Grand, which at their time were the largest hotels in the world.

Kerkorian also made major investments in the US automobile industry, buying shares in Chrysler, Ford and General Motors.

From the late 1980s he financed programs to support Armenia, particularly after the 1988 Spitak earthquake. His Lincy Foundation directed hundreds of millions of dollars into infrastructure and humanitarian projects.

name: Mikael Aramyants
subtitle: Oil magnate, financier, philanthropist
bio:
Mikael Aramyants (1843–1923) was born in the village of Kyatuk in Artsakh. He began as a trader and later became a shareholder in oil enterprises in Baku, amassing considerable wealth by the 1890s.

He worked in partnership with Alexander Mantashov and was part of major oil companies operating in Baku at the turn of the 20th century.

Aramyants was well known as a philanthropist in Tiflis. He financed the construction of the city hospital, the Majestic Hotel, and supported cultural and educational initiatives. His printing house published Armenian authors.

Despite his wealth, his final years were modest. He died in Tiflis in 1923 and was buried at the Armenian cemetery Khojivank.

name: Ruben Vardanyan
subtitle: Banker, investor, philanthropist
bio:
Ruben Vardanyan (born 1968) is an Armenian entrepreneur and philanthropist. In 1991 he founded the investment company Troika Dialog, which became one of the largest in Russia and the post-Soviet space.

Since the 2000s he has focused on projects connected with Armenia. He initiated the establishment of the international UWC Dilijan College and co-founded the Aurora Prize for Awakening Humanity.

In 2022 Vardanyan renounced Russian citizenship and moved to Artsakh, where he became involved in public and humanitarian activities. This step was widely regarded as a demonstration of commitment to Armenia.

After the events of 2023 he was taken prisoner in Baku. His name is associated both with investment activity in the post-Soviet market and with educational and humanitarian initiatives linked to Armenia and Artsakh.

name: Eduardo Eurnekian
subtitle: Entrepreneur, billionaire
bio:
Eduardo Eurnekian (born 1932) is an Argentine businessman of Armenian origin. He made his fortune in media and commerce and later founded Corporación América, which manages dozens of airports around the world.

Since the 2000s he has actively invested in Armenia. His company participated in the reconstruction of Zvartnots International Airport in Yerevan and the airport in Gyumri. He also invested in road construction, agriculture and energy projects.

Eurnekian supports educational and cultural initiatives of the Armenian diaspora. His name is linked to some of the largest foreign investments in the Armenian economy.

name: Alex Manoogian
subtitle: Businessman and philanthropist
bio:
Alex Manoogian (1901–1996) was born in Smyrna. After the massacres of 1922 he emigrated to the United States, settling in Detroit, where he built a successful business in auto parts.

From 1953 for over three decades he led the Armenian General Benevolent Union (AGBU). Under his leadership schools, cultural centers and hospitals were built in many countries.

He consistently supported educational initiatives and projects aimed at preserving Armenian identity in the diaspora. His activities contributed to the consolidation of Armenian communities in the 20th century.

name: Ivan Lazarevich Lazarev
subtitle: Merchant, court jeweler, philanthropist
bio:
Ivan Lazarevich Lazarev (1735–1801) came from an Armenian merchant family of New Julfa (Persia). In his youth he moved to Moscow, where he became wealthy trading precious stones and metals and working as a jeweler.

He became a court jeweler of Catherine II and executed orders for the imperial court. By the late 18th century he was among the most influential Moscow merchants.

He financed the construction of the Armenian church Surb Khach in Moscow. His descendants founded the Lazarev Institute of Oriental Languages, which became an important educational center for oriental studies and Armenian studies in Russia.

name: Georgy Lianozov
subtitle: Oil industrialist
bio:
Georgy Lianozov (1850–1916) was born in Baku to an Armenian family. By the late 19th century he was one of the major oil industrialists of the city. His company controlled significant volumes of oil extraction and refining, earning him the nickname 'Kerosene King'.

In the early 20th century the Lianozov family transferred part of their capital to Moscow, where they established a fish processing enterprise. Around it grew the settlement of Lianozovo, later incorporated into Moscow.

He also allocated funds to cultural and educational projects of the Armenian community. His name remains both in the history of Baku oil and in Moscow toponymy.

name: Sir Paul Chater
subtitle: Entrepreneur and philanthropist
bio:
Sir Paul Chater (1846–1926) was born in Calcutta to an Armenian family. As a young man he moved to Hong Kong, where he entered commerce and soon became a leading businessman in the colony.

He co-founded Hongkong Land, which played a central role in the development of the city's Central district. Chater participated in major infrastructure projects including land reclamation at Victoria Harbour, construction of the tramway and a power station.

He was a member of both the Executive and Legislative Councils of Hong Kong, representing the business community. For his service he was knighted by the British Crown.

Chater donated significant funds to education and culture, including La Martiniere College in Calcutta and the University of Hong Kong. He also supported the Armenian Church of Saint Nazareth.

name: Isaac Isaakovich Jamgarov
subtitle: Banker and philanthropist
bio:
Isaac Jamgarov (1845–1902) was the founder and co-owner of one of the largest banking houses of the Russian Empire, 'Jamgarov Brothers', established in Moscow in 1874 (or 1878). The bank's capital exceeded 5 million rubles, with an annual turnover of up to 1.4 billion rubles. It had offices in Moscow and St. Petersburg and financed industrial and energy projects.

The Jamgarov family served on the boards of leading banks and actively supported public initiatives: they funded the construction of a hospital in Karabakh, a memorial house at the Armenian cemetery, and contributed to the development of the district known as 'Jamgarovka'.

Isaac was killed in 1902 near the Armenian church in Moscow. In his memory, a memorial house was built, and the district retained his name.

name: Noubar Afeyan
subtitle: Entrepreneur, scientist and philanthropist
bio:
Noubar Afeyan (born 1962) is an Armenian-Canadian-American entrepreneur and bioengineer. He graduated from McGill University and MIT, earning a PhD in biochemical engineering in 1987.

In 1999 he founded Flagship Pioneering, under which more than 100 scientific enterprises were created, valued at billions of dollars, with hundreds of patents and dozens of drugs in clinical development. In 2009 he co-founded Moderna, one of the first companies to create a COVID-19 vaccine.

He is also active in philanthropy: co-founded the Aurora Humanitarian Initiative, UWC Dilijan, the IDeA Foundation and other projects aimed at developing Armenia and supporting the diaspora.

name: Sergey Galitsky Arutyunyan
subtitle: Founder of 'Magnit' retail chain, football patron
bio:
Sergey Galitsky (Arutyunyan) (born 1967) came from a family of Armenian origin. Later he took his wife's surname.

He is the founder and co-owner of 'Magnit', the largest retail chain in Russia, which grew into a retail empire with tens of thousands of stores and successfully held its IPO in 2006. He also owns the football club 'Krasnodar' and financed the construction of the stadium and the surrounding park in Krasnodar.

Despite his Armenian origin, Galitsky is perceived primarily as a Russian entrepreneur who played a significant role in the development of domestic retail and sports.

name: Samvel Karapetyan
subtitle: Founder of Tashir Group and philanthropist
bio:
Samvel Karapetyan (born 1965) is an Armenian-Russian billionaire, founder and owner of Tashir Group, a diversified holding in real estate, construction, energy and trade.

He actively invested in Armenia's social infrastructure: funded the construction of a hospital in Stepanakert and announced plans to invest $600 million in the country's energy sector.

In June 2025 he was detained after a public speech in support of the Armenian Apostolic Church. His arrest caused wide public resonance and was perceived as politically motivated. Despite the recognition of the detention as controversial, restrictive measures against him were extended.
